info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued May 27 at 9:51AM MDT by NWS Pueblo
info.description: ...INCREASING FIRE-WEATHER RISK THROUGH THIS WEEKEND... Across southeast Colorado, the fire-weather risk will increase in many areas through this weekend. Widely scattered thunderstorms are expected to form over the eastern mountains this afternoon, and spread eastward across the Interstate-25 corridor through this evening. This activity will be capable of producing gusty and erratic winds, lightning, and little to no precipitation. Lightning-induced ignitions, and subsequent spread of fires from strong outflow winds, may be a concern in areas where land-surface conditions are dry. Then for this weekend, a passing weather system will bring strong and gusty winds, along with very dry conditions, across the Interstate-25 corridor and the plains. Critical meteorological conditions are expected to develop in these areas, especially as temperatures become hot and relative humidity values fall into the single digits. These conditions are expected both Saturday and Sunday. However, many areas experienced appreciable amounts of precipitation late last week, and this past weekend into Monday. For some locations, this has resulted in unfavorable land-surface conditions for fire spread. Regardless, the ongoing drought conditions across the region will support favorable land-surface conditions for fire spread in other areas, as well. Where these drier land-surface conditions exist, the combination of strong winds, low relative humidity, and hot temperatures this weekend will have the potential to contribute to extreme fire behavior. It is important to remain extremely cautious given these conditions. Avoid burning or any outdoor activity that may produce a spark and start a wildfire.
